reviewText: Loved the movies by Wild Bill Elliott. He is a good actor!

I grew up with Wild Bill, especially as Red Rider. The only Red Rider on amazon that I have found is with Rocky Lane, not as good as Wild Bill. I will recommend this movie to anyone that  grew up in the late 40's and early 50's. It is a little hookey in today's environment but that is why I liked it.
this is not one of his best but it is still  avery good wild bill movie, him and gabby hayes work real good toghter
Ok movie.  Bill was older when he made it but still good picture.
While the assorted movies are a welcome addition to the Wild Bill Elliott collection, the quality of the prints was less than I expected.

With the technology that they had back in these days 30's thru early 40's they done a very good job. By today's standards this movie and hundreds like it made during the same era would not be considered a very high quality production but like I mentioned it was state of the art for the time.

Wild Bill Elliott's looks were not the best. To put it mildly he just wasn't the most handsome cowboy actor in the movies during this period but what he lacked in looks his honest approach to his acting style worked overtime for him.

In conclusion if you enjoy old westerns from this era and honest acting as well as black and white cowboy movies try this movie you are sure to enjoy it!

Anything Wild Bill is in is super and top rated for me.  He is such a great actor and I love the old westerns.  Guess I am just old myself but this is one of those that even my teenage grandsons have enjoyed with us.  Good time movie.

Republic Pictures present "CALLING WILD BILL ELLIOTT" (1943) (55 mins/B&W) (Dolby digitally remastered) --- relive those thrilling days when Wild Bill Elliott took us down the dusty trails with hard riding and straight shooting hitting the bull's eye with excitement every time ... the Wild Bill Elliott series of B-Westerns were a staple of Saturday matinees in the 1930s and 1940s ...  Wild Bill fans know one of his trademarks was wearing his pistols backwards butts front in his holsters, when he drew he would draw in the normal way flipping the guns around with a twist of his wrist, this was different from other B-Western heroes of that day ... don't miss any of the Wild Bill Elliott features loaded with action that will leave you wanting more of his B-Western adventures.

Under Spencer Gordon Bennet (Director), Harry Grey (Producer), Anthony Coldeway  - Screenwriter), Luci Ward (Short Story Author), Ernest W. Miller (Cinematographer), Mort Glickman (Original Music) ------ the cast includes Bill Elliott (Wild Bill Elliott), George Francis Hayes (Gabby Hayes), Anne Jeffreys (Edith Richards), Herbert Heyes (Governor Nichols), Robert 'Buzz' Henry (John Culver Jr), Fred Kohler Jr. (John Culver), Roy Barcroft (Captain Carson), Eve March (Mary Culver), Burr Caruth (Grandpa Culver), Bud Geary (Dean), Lynton Brent (Ranch hand) ------ our hero Wild Bill Elliott moved from Columbia Pictures to Republic where he received bigger parts and better scripts, teamed with George Gabby Hayes and Anne Jeffreys in a series of eight films ... the plot line has our hero Wild Bill Elliott going up against a ruthless Governor Herbert Heyes who has the ranchers land in his sight ... Gabby Hayes keeps bragging about how he and Wild Bill cleaned up every town west of the pecos, even though he's never met Wild Bill before ... when Wild Bill shows up, Gabby doesn't know him until Wild Bill gets the point and puts his arm around Gabby as if the two were old saddle mates ... the beautiful Anne Jeffreys is the heroine, with veteran badmens Roy Barcroft, Fred Kohler Jr. and Bud Geary bringing in all the evil this Republic Picture could muster ... some dark scenes for a B-Western when the villain tries to burn a youth with his cigarette ... wonderful supporting cast of veterans players as Gabby brags, "Why I was so close to Wild Bill that we wore the same hat." ---- they just don't make 'em like this anymore and Republic Pictures was one of the leaders of exciting B-Westerns and Serials.

* The eight films featuring Wild Bill Elliott, George Gabby Hayes and Anne Jeffreys are as follows:
1. CALLING WILD BILL ELLIOTT (4/20/43)
2. THE MAN FROM THUNDER RIVER (6/11/43)
3. BORDERTOWN GUN FIGHTERS (7/8/43)
4. WAGON TRACKS WEST (8/19/43)
5. DEATH VALLEY MANHUNT (9/25/43)
6. OVERLAND MAIL ROBBERY (11/20/43)
7. MOJAVE FIREBRAND (3/19/44)
8. HIDDEN VALLEY OUTLAWS (4/2/44)

Special Footnote, there is no doubt in anyone's mind that Gordon Nance from Pattonsburg, Mo, later known at William "Wild Bill" Elliott (the Peaceable Man) was the best Red Ryder on the big screen ... also the latest Bobby J. Copeland's book on "Bill Elliott:The Peaceable Man" is chuck full of answers to all the questions his fans had from early on...plenty of thrills, adventure and loaded with action. My personal favorites were the "Red Ryder Series" or "The Great Adventures of Wild Bill Hickok" an ongoing character that would appear in many films to come...as Hickok and Wild Bill Saunders. Elliott was a natural for the western, his riding abilities and fight scenes were the caliber of Buck Jones, Johnny Mack Brown and Bob Steele...good reading for all you wranglers out there...I found myself being transported back in time, Mr. Copeland's book has opened my eyes to what a wonderful unselfish person Bill Elliott was...only wish I could have met him. He was one of a kind...a peaceable man!...published by Empire Publising and available on Amazon and Empire Publications Inc ... it's no small wonder that William Elliott's name was at the top of the list, working with the top directors of the day Howard P. Bretherton, Spencer Gordon Bennett, Joseph Kane, Wallace A. Grissell, Leslie Selander and R.G. Springsteen all under Republic Pictures banner.

Second special footnote, veteran actor George "Gabby" Hayes...was a steady favorite as a hitchrack, was chosen five years in succession as one of the 10 best money-making Western sidekick stars...like most western comics, had his share of narrow escapes being thrown from his horse, burned by blanks...but that was all in a days work ... his one-liners will never be forgotten --- "You're dern tootin'"..."Never trust a female, they're pure poyzin"...or my all-time favorite ~ "Persnickgordy Women"...this crusty old-timer stole many a scene from Bill Elliott, William Boyd, John Wayne and Randolph Scott.

BIOS:
1. Bill Elliott (aka: Gordon Nance)
Date of birth: 16 October 1903 - Pattonsburg, Missouri
Date of death: 26 November 1965 - Las Vegas, Nevada
2. George 'Gabby' Hayes (aka: George Francis Hayes)
Date of birth: 7 May 1885 - Wellsville, New York
Date of death: 9 February 1969 - Burbank, California
3. Anne Jeffreys (aka: Anne Carmichael)
Date of birth: 26 January 1923 - Goldsboro, North Carolina
Date of death: Still Living
4.  Spencer Gordon Bennet  (Director)
Date of birth:  5 January 1893 - Brooklyn, New York, New York
Date of death:  8 October 1987 - Santa Monica, California

Great job releasing "Calling Wild Bill Elliott" (1943) - Wild Bill Elliott, the digital transfere with a clean, clear and crisp print...looking forward to more high quality releases from the vintage serial era of the '20s, '30s & '40s and B-Westerns...order your copy now from Amazon where there are plenty of copies available on VHS, stay tuned once again for top notch action mixed with deadly adventure --- if you enjoyed this title, why not check out VCI Entertainment where they are experts in releasing B-Westerns and Serials --- just the way we like 'em

Total Time: 55 min on VHS ~ Republic Video ~ (1/01/1998)

After Gordon Elliott starred as Bill Hickok in a Columbia serial and then some Columbia features, his name got changed to "Wild Bill" Elliott -- and that was who he played in his first series at Republic, before becoming "Red Ryder" in yet another series and then moving up to A-budget westerns as "William Elliott." This movie introduces the new character, teams him with George "Gabby" Hayes, the best sidekick in show business, drops in perky Ann Jeffreys as the leading lady, pits him against a crooked territorial governor with Roy Barcroft as his chief henchman, and then we can just stand back and enjoy the fireworks.
Good older western.  Always like Gabby  Hayes.
A big old Western fan as my father was before me
Great old western, Wild Bill was a good guy for sure.

Gabby Hayes I guess you  would call him the comic relief, adds a little extra  to these wild Bill westerns love the two guns on wild bill with the stocks backwards ! what movie cowboy wore his guns that way? don you know?

Just as I remembered them.real good feel with all the action you'd expect.for
 My $$$ this was one of the better series of westerns. Durango Kid-are u listening?
A great old time western, they could not make this one today..
ecellent fare for a Republic B western.  Bill Elliott was great.  you always knew where he stood.
I am very satisfied with this purchase.
